content.title: The Six Ratios
content.body:
Trigonometry is the study of relationships between the sides and angles of a right-angled triangle. 

With respect to angle \(\theta\):
1. \(\sin \theta = \text{Opposite/Hypotenuse}\)
2. \(\cos \theta = \text{Adjacent/Hypotenuse}\)
3. \(\tan \theta = \text{Opposite/Adjacent}\)

**Reciprocals:**
- \(\text{cosec } \theta = 1/\sin \theta\)
- \(\sec \theta = 1/\cos \theta\)
- \(\cot \theta = 1/\tan \theta\)
content.analogy: Think of it like a recipe. If you know the angle, the ratios tell you exactly how much 'Side A' you need relative to 'Side B' to build that specific triangle.

content.title: The Trigonometric Table
content.body:
You must know the values for \(0^\circ, 30^\circ, 45^\circ, 60^\circ,\) and \(90^\circ\).

**Key Values to Memorize:**
- \(\sin 30^\circ = 1/2\)
- \(\sin 45^\circ = 1/\sqrt{2}\)
- \(\sin 60^\circ = \sqrt{3}/2\)
- \(\tan 45^\circ = 1\)

content.instruction: These three identities are the 'tools' used to solve almost all 4-mark proving questions:

content.exactPhrase: When you are stuck on a proof involving \(\tan, \cot, \sec,\) or \(\text{cosec}\), convert everything into terms of \(\sin\) and \(\cos\). Most expressions simplify much faster this way.

content.title: Tangent and Cotangent
content.body:
Always remember that \(\tan\) and \(\cot\) can be expressed as ratios of \(\sin\) and \(\cos\):

- \(\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\)
- \(\cot \theta = \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}\)

content.question: Evaluate: \(\sin 60^\circ \cos 30^\circ + \sin 30^\circ \cos 60^\circ\)
content.explanation: Substitute values: \((\sqrt{3}/2 \times \sqrt{3}/2) + (1/2 \times 1/2)\). This becomes \(3/4 + 1/4 = 4/4 = 1\). Note: This is also the formula for \(\sin(A+B)\) which is \(\sin(60+30) = \sin 90^\circ = 1\).
